textHTML:
“Emotional reasoning” is a cognitive distortion where our emotions take precedence over logic and facts when we’re making decisions. As a result, we may see situations incorrectly and make choices that don’t align with reality.

For example, someone might refuse to visit friends simply because they feel sad and unmotivated to socialize, without acknowledging that spending time with them might actually improve their mood.

Relying on emotional reasoning can lead to flawed conclusions and decisions, so it’s essential to balance your feelings with more objective considerations.
dialogSummary: In this conversation, Person 1 relies on how they feel to avoid going on a date, dismissing logical points and facts. Person 2 encourages a more objective view and points out other factors that could influence the outcome.
dialog: I don’t want to go on a date. I’m just in a bad mood.
But you said you like this guy. Don’t you want to give it a shot and see how it turns out?
No, I’m convinced I’ll ruin everything because of how I’m feeling. I just feel insecure and foolish.
You can’t really know unless you try. Maybe the date will go well, and you’ll realize your worries were unnecessary.
